 No evidence except for the multiple independat and bipartisan reports that came at the same time that directly contradicted his.
 
 From a practical standpoint the disagreement is over exactly what Patraeus's job is. His job, as a general in the US army, was to provide the report that represented the views of his chain of command. Essentially, his job was to get up there and further Bushs views and agenda. 
 
 Moveon.org incorrectly felt that his job was to get up there and give the most impartial and realistic report he was capable of providing regarding the situation in Iraq. That is simply not the case.
 
 This is actually fairly similar to the charges that floated around regarding Powell after he got up and presented a pack of lies at the UN. He was the secretary of state. His job was to go to the UN and submit the report he was told to submit. Even Powell later said he did not personally believe most of what was in the report, but it did not matter. His job was not to deliver his opinion, it was to deliver the report he was told to deliver. 
 
 
I think there is a clear difference between saying something political about a candidate, and saying something political about a member of military personnel who was giving a military assessment and doing his job. Personally, I can't imagine that anyone couldn't see the difference. Was what Jim said about Hillary Clinton tacky? Yes. But I think attacking a general by distorting his name in a very insulting way, who is not even involved in politics and was just doing his job, is a whole lot tackier.

It his how he ended up with his job...that and the fact that nobody who was actually qualified was willing to take it. Keep in mind that Patraeus was not their first choice, or second, or even third. He was the 4th guy that they offered the job to. His role as a combat commander stretches clear back to....2003. The guy got where he is by serving as an aid to senior generals. He is nothing but an REMF who ended up leading the occupation of Iraq despite the fact that he has absolutly no experience that would suggest that he is qualified for the job. So how did he get it?? Politics. Since day one of the Iraq war he has been a vocal supporter of every hair brained scheme the Bush administration has tossed out. He has publicly come out and endorsed every idiotic, nonsensical thing they have done. 
 
 Basically, after firing everybody who disagreed with them for 7 years, the Bush adminstration appointed a politicized weasel to lead the occuptation of Iraq, and now we are all supposed to pretend to be offended by the fact that he is having to take political flack??? What a joke. Despite absolutly no notable actions since 2004, Patraeus has earned 2 shiny new stars...unless now we are handing out promotions for writing pro Bush war plan editorials for the Washington Post.
 
 I do not know patraeus personally, so my comments are based entirely on the public information available on his service record and the impressions I have gotten from other military or former military officers. Given that MoveOn doesn't seem to give much thought to the fact that if we did exactly what they would want and just pull all the troops out ASAP it would be disastrous, we can assume that they feel Petreaus was betraying people by not going along with the idea that the troops should be pulled out immediately. If that's what they consider betrayal, then MoveOn is wrong. 

 
 No, I think they felt he betrayed us because his report was so far removed from the other independant reports that had been presented that there is little doubt that his was at the very least insanely optimistic and far more likey just a pack of lies and manipulated data. 
 
 As far as pulling troops out now being disasterous...who says? The only people who seem to be parroting that are the same leaders who have been wrogn about EVERYTHING related to Iraq so far. They have NO CREDIBILITY, so lets stop repeating whatever BS is coming out of their mouths.
 
 From a practical standpoint, there are only 2 possible outcomes when it comes to the situation in Iraq. First, we can stay until we have gotten the government of Iraq to the point that they have an absolute iron grip over the country...basically stick around until the government is so tyrannical that nobody DARE oppose them. We can ensure that they remain in power, and carry their water, until the very concept of "rights" has been completely wiped from the IRaqi consciousness. Basically, we can turn Iraq into another Saudi Arabia. All the while, while we are nurturing and helping this iron fisted, tyrannical government along, Iraqis who do not want to live under a totalitarian religous regime and those who do will continue to kill each other in the streets.
 
 OR, we can leave. If we leave, those who want to live under a totalitarian religous regime and those who do not will continue to kill each other in the street until they work something out, which they eventually WILL. They will end up with a government that everybody can live with, though it will almost certainly not be the western style of democracy that we have tried to shove down their throat since it is incompatible with their religous, cultural, and historical background.
 
 Those are literally the only 2 possible outcomes. Nobody who claims to give a damn about the Iraqis or freedom should even be considering #1. 
 
 The simple fact of the matter is that we have screwed Iraq up so badly that we cannot possibly fix it, and every single thing we try to do to fix it is absolutly destined to make things worse.
jyoshu

No, I think they felt he betrayed us because his report was so far removed from the other independant reports that had been presented

 
 ??? How could they have felt it was far removed when they hadn't even heard it yet? Did you not realize the ad was published BEFORE Petraeus even testified?
 
 
As far as pulling troops out now being disasterous...who says?

 
 Pretty much everyone, other than those on the anti-war fringe. Even almost everyone against the war is in favor of a stepped-down program which pulls them out in phases rather than just immediately sending everyone home essentially at once. They hold to a quicker withdrawal, but few people, relatively speaking, are for pulling all the troops out at once.
 
 
Those are literally the only 2 possible outcomes. Nobody who claims to give a damn about the Iraqis or freedom should even be considering #1. 
 
 The simple fact of the matter is that we have screwed Iraq up so badly that we cannot possibly fix it, and every single thing we try to do to fix it is absolutly destined to make things worse.

 
 I agree with you there. It's a screwed up situation.
daewoo

??? How could they have felt it was far removed when they hadn't even heard it yet? Did you not realize the ad was published BEFORE Petraeus even testified?

 
 But AFTER the Bush administration had already released portions of the report...apparently to counter all the bipartisan reports that painted such a poor picture of Iraq. Apparently they fialed to recognize that they have NO CREDIBILITY left at all, so releasing selected portions of the report didn't help them.
 
 
 
Pretty much everyone, other than those on the anti-war fringe. Even almost everyone against the war is in favor of a stepped-down program which pulls them out in phases rather than just immediately sending everyone home essentially at once. They hold to a quicker withdrawal, but few people, relatively speaking, are for pulling all the troops out at once.

 
 It would not be possible to pull out all the troops at once. Even moveon.org recognizes this. Even an "immediate withdrawal of all troops" would take 6 months. You simply cannot evac 160,000 men and all their equipment in a day.
jyoshu

It would not be possible to pull out all the troops at once. Even moveon.org recognizes this. Even an "immediate withdrawal of all troops" would take 6 months. You simply cannot evac 160,000 men and all their equipment in a day.

 
 Well, that's pretty much the point. I'm glad we agree.
Kronus

Well, that's pretty much the point. I'm glad we agree.

 
 I laughed when I read that. Thanks for putting a chuckle into my morning!
